item.description:
From Jen Nedbalsky, curator and organizer of YOUTH PRODUCING CHANGE at the Human
Rights Watch International Film Festival:

I wanted to be in touch to suggest a film screening for your members. We have an incredible
film screening and reception happening on Fri Jan 16, and we
hope you can join us!

The 78 minute film program includes 9 short films made by teens
from around the world, as they document the human rights issues
they themselves face. The films are uplifting, funny and
thought provoking. They will inspire you and your members to
make change in your communities. We'll be bringing in
filmmakers from Kentucky, Brooklyn and 2 from Boston for a Q&A
and special reception to follow.



YOUTH PRODUCING CHANGE


A program of short films was directed and produced by youth
from across the globe. Armed with digital cameras, computers,
and their own boundless creativity, these young people bravely
expose human rights issues faced by themselves and their
communities. A question and answer session with youth
filmmakers--followed by a free reception at the school of the
Museum of Fine Arts--follows screening.

The Countdown by Rene Dongo (US, 2007, 6 min.) An artist hopes
society can work to fill the empty space left by 9/11.

Women Empowerment by Bridges to Understanding (South Africa,
2007,
5 min.). A look at the harsh reality South African mothers face
in raising children alone in their township.

I Want My Parents Back by Media Arts Center San Diego students
(US/Mexico, 2007, 11 min). The impact of US immigration
policies on families.

Islands of the People by Atira Women's Resource Society
students (Canada, 2007, 6 min.) A thirteen-year-old girl makes
a commitment to learn the Haida language from her grandmother,
one of the last living people who can speak, read, and write in
Haida.

The True Cost of Coal by Appalachian Media Institute, Appalshop
Inc. students (2007, 8 min.). Mountain communities rally to
protect their rights, land, and health.

The Hidden Cost of Cashmere by Zane Scheuerlein (2007,
3 min.). America's appetite for cheap consumer goods links us
with desertification and the growing environmental crisis.

A Maid Is Not A Slave by Mariama Ba Girls Boarding School
students (Senegal, West Africa, 2007, 5 min.). Kine, a young
Senegalese domestic worker, is mistreated by the family that
employs her.

Slave Label by Queen Elizabeth School students (UK, 2008, 18
min.).
Two teenage girls embark on an eye-opening journey as they
discover the dark truth behind the fashion industry.

Playing with the Other Tigers by Zachary Lennon-Simon (2007, 10
min). The story of two childhood friends, one Muslim, one half-
Jewish, whose friendship takes on added significance after
9/11.


If you've seen Born into Brothels, you know that children with cameras can make a powerful impact. Come out to the MFA for what should be a most memorable collection of short films from the perspective of the children involved. A Q and A with many of the directors should be fascinating, and an opportunity to speak with them, the curator of the films, and with each other at a reception at the Museum School of the Arts is an opportunity not to be missed!

Please get your tickets well in advance as programs such as these at the MFA tend to sell out with long stand-by lines. Tickets can be purchased at MFA

Also, I highly suggest you take the T. Parking at the MFA tends to be an oxymoron.
